ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Music theory about meter and rhythm
How to analyze classical music and exotic music

Understanding of meter in music - its biological underpinnings and different forms. Also, an understanding of various rhythms (e.g. tresillo), and some mathematical and graphical ways of representing these things.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: interesting content, concepts build nicely on one another. Presentation days were fun and well-timed, and the music Professor Cohn had us listen to was generally enjoyable/interesting.
Weaknesses: at times felt a bit slow, especially in the middle of the course. Perhaps could have involved more listening to music. Assignments were sometimes unclear, especially towards the end.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Possibly? I usually enjoyed the course, and thought it was interesting, but didn't come away from the class wanting to further pursue mathematical representations of music. (I will continue to learn about rhythm, but from a musician rather than academic perspective). In light of this, I probably would recommend my past self to take a different class. This said, I think my ability to perceive and generate rhythm has improved. If I had unlimited time/classes, I would at least shop Music 416 (advanced version of this class, also with Professor Cohn); since my classes are limited, I almost certainly will not.
Other people might have different takeaways, and perhaps even now are writing about how excited they are to take Music 416.
